eventName: CyberWomen on Capitol Hill: EWF - Women's Cybersecurity Leadership Symposium
location: Russell Senate Office Building  Room 325  Washington, DC 20002
venue: Russell Senate Office Building  Room 325  Washington, DC 20002
abstract: Join the Executive Women's Forum on Capitol Hill to celebrate DC CyberWeek, champion women's leadership and learn how to have a voice with Congressional Members and Staff. We will host a Fireside chat with cybersecurity industry and government women leaders, engage in open forum Q&A, participate in professional roundtable discussions on women's cybersecurity roles in Washington, D.C. and collaborate in dynamic networking to meet inspiring Washington, D.C. women.
speakerName: Anna Wheeler
title: Women's Cybersecurity Leadership Symposium

venue: Ponte Vedra Inn & Club, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL
abstract:
Organizations embracing clouds, elastic workloads, mobile, IoT, and big data must shift security from an afterthought to a core practice of safeguarding data from endpoints to the cloud. Featuring a case study presentation by Experian and using examples from other leading enterprises, this session discusses how CISOs can:

- reduce the attack surface by regaining visibility across hybrid IT environments
- automate processes to build security into DevOps
- secure the journey to the cloud from beginning to end
speakerName: Chris Carlson, Vice President, Product Management, Qualys | Peeyush Patel, Vice President, Information Security, Experian
title: Continuous Visibility and Security in a Hybrid Enterprise

abstract:
Moderator: John Willis

Panelists: Syamla Bandla, Vice President, Global Cloud Operations and DevOps, Qualys | Stephanie Derdouri, Director Vulnerability Management, Information Security, Fannie Mae | Lisa Phillips, Vice President of Engineering, Fastly | Chenxi Wang, founder, The Jane Bond Project
speakerName: Syamla Bandla, Vice President, Global Cloud Operations and DevOps, Qualys
title: DevSecOps Panel – It’s a People Thing

abstract: Organizations are rapidly shifting to digital business processes, DevOps methods and cloud-based infrastructure, while threat landscapes evolve at an equally rapid pace. This presentation will address how companies are leveraging integrated cloud-based security and compliance tools to gain continuous visibility of their security and compliance posture across entire global IT environments and development life cycles.
speakerName: Mike Quealey, Technical Account Manager, Qualys
title: Security and Visibility for Digital Transformation and the Cloud Era

abstract:
It would seem the more we “build a better mousetrap” the better the threats become. Will machine learning and AI be used against us in the future? Will these and other innovations be hacked and used for gain? Will the Crime as a Business platform take off where business competitors are utilizing these attacks for the upper hand? Perhaps the cars that are being hacked will evolve into driverless vehicles that are hacking companies from inside there own parking lots. What about drones?

So many questions, let’s see what our experts say on this panel.
speakerName: Tony Yodice, Technical Account Manager, Qualys
title: Panel: What Will They Think of Next (Emerging Threats)

abstract:
Moderator: Mr. Henry Sienkiewicz, Chief Innovation and Revenue Officer, Secure Channels, Inc. (confirmed)

Panelists:
Mr. Frederic J. "Ric" Agardy, Chief Architect, Military SATCOM, The Aerospace Corporation (confirmed)
Col Robert K. Lyman, USAF, Chief Information Officer/J6, Joint Special Operations Command (confirmed)
Mr. Nicholas Nilan, Director, Public Sector Product Development, Verizon (confirmed)
Mr. Mark Butler, Chief Information Security Officer, Qualys (confirmed)
speakerName: Mark Butler, CISO, Qualys
title: Panel: Information Technology Environment – The Market Place

abstract: Today’s digitally transforming enterprise relies on dynamic, hybrid IT environments that can create security and compliance visibility silos. Regaining single-pane visibility across data centers, clouds and endpoints is key to extending a risk-based security approach to these assets. The talk will share a new approach to gain global visibility and reduce risk for today’s business.
speakerName: Faeq Abu Khair, Director, Technical Account Management, Qualys
title: A Risk-Based Security Approach for Today’s Global Digital Enterprise

abstract: As enterprises race towards digital transformation, CISOs must redefine their role on the digital business team. By enabling infrastructure agility and visibility, they can create business value and become a trusted partner. This keynote will discuss how CISOs can build security into accelerated technology implementations while maintaining continuous risk reduction for today’s hyperconnected business.
speakerName: Mark Butler, Chief Information Security Officer, Qualys, Inc.
title: Digital Transformation and the New Role CISOs Need to Play

eventName: ISACA IIA 4th Annual IT Hacking Conference
venue: Summit West, 500 W Madison St, Chicago, Illinois
abstract: Heightened compliance and security requirements require that organizations comply with multiple regulations while managing a security baseline. Top-down GRC provides structure, but little evidence data, while Bottom-Up approaches miss links to the bigger GRC picture. In this talk Qualys will discuss the ‘harmonized approach’, a uniform way customers address many compliance and risk requirements.
speakerName: Mark Butler, CISO, Qualys
title: Harmonized GRC Approach with Qualys Mandate Based Reporting

location: iContact, 2121 RDU Center Drive, 4th Floor, Morrisville, NC
abstract:
A Top 10 List for Better AppSec (HINT: IT’S NOT THE OWASP TOP TEN)
By far the best known “list” in the arena of application security is the OWASP Top Ten.  There’s no question it has helped greatly over the years to raise awareness of common vulnerabilities in web applications like SQL injection, XSS, and CSRF.  But in the end that’s all it is – an awareness document.  This session will introduce and examine a different top ten list that is aimed at developers who are actually writing the code and building the software.  It is known as the OWASP Top 10 Proactive Controls and it’s chock-full of practical, application security goodness. The audience will learn how secure development techniques and prescriptive guidance provided in the Top 10 Proactive Controls can move the needle toward having highly secure applications throughout an organization.
speakerName: Deve Ferguson, Solution Architect, Qualys
title: A Top 10 List for Better AppSec (HINT: IT’S NOT THE OWASP TOP TEN)

abstract:
In this presentation, we will discuss a year-long study of exploits kits, attacks and vulnerability attributes and learn how to use them for prioritization. We will share best practices

for improving remediation and reducing risk.



After completing this session, you will be able to:

Understand how attacks happen in real world
Understand Exploits and Vulnerabilities
Understand how to prioritize remediation.
Reduce overall risk.
speakerName: Amol Sarwate, Director of Vulnerability Labs, Qualys
title: Prioritize Vulnerability Remediation

eventName: BrightTalk Summit: Deploying and Managing Successful Cloud Apps
abstract:
With agility enable successful cloud deployments to meet the demands of scale.
With visibility drive reducing MTBF(mean-time-between-failures) and MTTR(mean-time-to-resolve).
With security ensure your Cloud environments are secure.
speakerName: Syamla Banda, VP of Global Cloud Operations & DevOps, Qualys
title: How to Achieve Agility, Visibility and Security in the Cloud

abstract: Data management can turn the promise of apps into security team peril. How can we prevent exposure of location tracking, application protocols and financial date from giving an attacker the edge?
speakerName: Jason Kent, Vice President, Web Application Security, Qualys
title: RSA Conference 2017 P2P Discussion: Promise and Peril in the App Era

eventName: RSA Conference 2017 P2P Discussion: Surviving DDOS Attacks in the Age of Mirai-like IoT Botnets
abstract: This group will share experiences and explore prevention, remediation, and hack-back strategies to improve best practices for fighting future IoT botnet DDoS attacks.

title: Security as an enabler to Digital Transformation

location: Moscone Center North, San Francisco, CA (Room 130)
abstract: Cloud services, Continuous Integration, and Continuous Deployment require security teams to adapt security controls to DevOps processes. Learn how security delivered as a service helps security teams work with DevOps to embed continuous security into IT and application infrastructure for improved and automated auditing, compliance and control of applications.
speakerName: Chris Carlson, Vice President, Cloud Agent Platform
title: DevSecOps – Building Continuous Security into IT and App Infrastructures

location: Marriott Marquee, San Francisco, CA (Yerba Buena 5)
abstract: 2016 saw the widest variety of information security incidents ever, with traditional phishing attacks and advanced malware competing with an explosion of new ransomware and IoT-based DDoS attacks.  The growth of cloud usage and unmanaged next generation endpoint devices are stretching threat vectors and creating greater concerns of data breaches and worse.  Despite these issues, the benefits of cloud and IoT are profound, and even the most tightly regulated industries are moving to loosen up restrictions to the adoption of these new technologies.  2017 promises to be an even faster paced year for information security.  In this panel, our industry luminaries look at the important areas of concern and opportunity for the information security professional in the coming year and answer your top of mind questions.  What are likely to be the most impactful security incidents in 2017?  Is the enterprise’s perception of its risks in this new world aligned with reality?  How well are cloud providers addressing their security responsibilities?  Is application security keeping up?  Are we adequately leveraging important solutions such as identity management and encryption?
speakerName: Chris Carlson, Vice President, Cloud Agent Platform
title: Panel - Between the Cloud and IoT: Risks, Threats and Opportunities

abstract: Abstract: Penetration testing is complex, costly, and often perceived as another compliance burden with little business value. With such a heavy focus on technologies; operational root causes, business drivers, and key stakeholders quickly become neglected. The goal of this session is to provide solutions that advance the state of penetration testing in a way that maximizes business value.
speakerName: Greg Anderson, Technical Account Manager, Qualys and Michael Cook, Cyber Security Researcher and Pentester, CERT Division of the Software Engineering Institute, Carnegie Mellon University
title: Operationally Focused Pen-testing

abstract: Jason Kent is Vice President, Web Application Security at Qualys. Prior to that, he held technical security positions at Veracode, BlueCoat, Aruba and Verizon. Through more than a decade of dedicated AppSec experience, he has established expertise in AppSec PenTesting, AppSec program architecture and AppSec tools. His efforts helping Fortune 500 companies to maintain continuous security and compliance spans Application Security, Infrastructure Security, Wireless and Physical Security. Kent has spoken at conferences such as ISC2 Security Congress, Northeastern OWASP events, and for Qualys at RSA and Black Hat. A US Navy Submarine Force Veteran, Kent is also passionate about putting security people together with their stakeholders.
speakerName: Jason Kent, Vice President, Product Management, Web Application Security, Qualys
title: Security in the App Era: Building Strength for an Interconnected World

abstract:
As we all connect everything in our homes to the Internet, we need to seriously consider the security of the endpoints we place in our homes and use everyday. Our security cameras, water heaters, garage door openers and others, are offering control and convenience like we have never seen and their use can be exposing sensitive data to the world.

IOT is not at all about the Internet, we already know quite a bit about the Internet and its problems. IOT is all about the "Things." Have we placed enough importance on the "Things" from a security perspective? From exposing WIFI passwords via connected light bulbs to location tracking of family members to data collected regarding consumption rates, there are many problems that IOT can bring with all the solutions its known for. 

Taking a deep look into a few of these devices and understanding their communication reveals that we are not only opting into a perfect world for attackers to compromise but, we are exposing our homes, our families, to attacks against these devices. 

Utilizing web security and infrastructure security assessment practices we will take a deep dive into IOT devices and Applications to show the types of attacks that are available and how to mitigate the risk this new attack surface presents. We'll show some resources to see Internet connected devices all over the world as well as illustrate what can happen if these devices are breached.
speakerName: Jason Kent, Vice President, Product Management, Web Application Security, Qualys
title: IOT Application Security - Are you exposing your home to an attack?

abstract: What's with cross-site request forgery? A decade ago it was supposed to be a "sleeping giant", preparing to wake and inflict havoc upon the worldwide web application landscape. But the doomsday scenario never materialized and you don't even seem to hear much about it anymore. In this talk, 10 years after disclosing massive CSRF vulnerabilities in Netflix's main website, I will cover all things CSRF! We'll discuss why hackers are or aren't exploiting CSRF, data breaches that may or may not have occurred due to CSRF, review CSRF protection mechanisms built into many modern development frameworks, and look at how WAFs (web application firewalls) and RASP (run-time application protection) can potentially be leveraged to block CSRF attacks. I'll also cover how black-box scanning tools test for CSRF vulnerabilities and discuss their false positive/false negative rates. Finally, I'll demonstrate some manual testing techniques with Burp to help you quickly identify CSRF issues.
speakerName: Dave Ferguson
title: It's All About That C-SURF, No Trouble

speakerName: Tim White and Shailesh Athalye
title: Achieving Uniform Compliance and Risk Management Through Harmonized GRC

speakerName: Frank Catucci
title: AppSec Enigma and Mirage - When Good Ideas Can Go Awry

location: Metro Toronto Convention Center, Toronto, ON, Canada
abstract: IT departments are expected to protect their organizations from existing vulnerabilities and from the thousands of new ones disclosed every year. Unfortunately, when it comes to vulnerability remediation, many organizations face an excess of cyber-threats and a shortage of infosec professionals. To weather this storm, IT departments must prioritize remediation, so that they can promptly fix the vulnerabilities that represent the greatest risk to their organization at any given point in time. In this presentation we will discuss a year-long study of exploits kits, attacks and vulnerability attributes and learn how to use them for prioritization. We will share best practices for improving remediation and reducing risk in the age of vulnerability disclosure overload.
speakerName: Amol Sarwate, Director of Vulnerability Labs, Qualys
title: Overwhelmed By Security Vulnerabilities? Learn How To Prioritize Remediation

location: Ford Motor Conference and Event Center, Dearborn, MI
abstract: Panel Description: By far, the biggest security threat facing companies is employees. Everything from weak expiration policies to zombie accounts can put your organization at risk. Education and awareness have never been more important. Join this panel of experts as they discuss the use of technology and smart policies to effectively educate and inform the humans.
speakerName: Jason Kent, Vice President, Product Management, Web Application Security, Qualys
title: Panel: You've Got Humans on Your Network

abstract: Data privacy and data security have unequal footing within browsers and mobile apps. Data security relies on technical controls like the Same Origin Policy and sandboxing. Browsers must weigh the trade-offs between improving APIs for developers and limiting the ability of attackers to abuse those APIs. This presentation covers concepts for building and breaking privacy barriers.
speakerName: Mike Shema
title: Building and Breaking Privacy Barriers

abstract: HVAC systems are being hacked! Surveillance cameras are being co-opted! Refrigerators are sending spam! The Internet of Things (IoT) and control systems deliver tremendous convenience, but at a cost. Does your organization know how to assess the risks introduced by IoT and control systems? Do you have the correct methodology? The right tools?
